pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 7: Features for programmatic construction of objects

content.raw: I added a failing test \([de6ea31](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/commits/de6ea31e2870a4f020eefe0ae3abc161204d3f16?at=sdf_component)\) that uses `ForwardStep`. The test world is a sphere falling and a static box on which the sphere is supposed to land. The sphere instead goes through the box. Running the world in gazebo with DART works as expected.
content.html: I added a failing test (de6ea31) that uses ForwardStep. The test world is a sphere falling and a static box on which the sphere is supposed to land. The sphere instead goes through the box. Running the world in gazebo with DART works as expected.

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 7: Features for programmatic construction of objects

content.raw: The issue is that `world->addSkeleton` is called [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/src/de6ea31e2870a4f020eefe0ae3abc161204d3f16/dartsim/src/Base.hh#lines-181) before the skeleton is populated with collision shapes. `addSkeleton` is responsible for adding collision shapes to DARTs collision checker, and I don't think there is a way to update the collision checker after this call. We should be able to fix the failing test since it's using `ConstructWorld` and passing in a whole `SDF:World`, but this poses a problem if we're trying to add links and their collisions incrementally. Maybe we can add a \`Model::Finalize\` or something similar?
content.html: The issue is that world->addSkeleton is called here before the skeleton is populated with collision shapes. addSkeleton is responsible for adding collision shapes to DARTs collision checker, and I don't think there is a way to update the collision checker after this call. We should be able to fix the failing test since it's using ConstructWorld and passing in a whole SDF:World, but this poses a problem if we're trying to add links and their collisions incrementally. Maybe we can add a `Model::Finalize` or something similar?

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 7: Features for programmatic construction of objects

content.raw:
Since [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/42/basic-physics-system/diff) PR was merged, `ign-gazebo` depends on this branch.

Since the `ign-gazebo` [pipelines](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/407) is passing using `ign-physics` [debs](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/6cd0b0c9b97b17959bd785e37252295092a8644d/bitbucket-pipelines.yml?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#bitbucket-pipelines.yml-34), I guess the debs were built using this branch...? 

If this is all true, then merging this soon should save people some detective work.
content.html:
Since this PR was merged, ign-gazebo depends on this branch.

Since the ign-gazebo pipelines is passing using ign-physics debs, I guess the debs were built using this branch...?

If this is all true, then merging this soon should save people some detective work.

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 7: Features for programmatic construction of objects

content.raw:
you also call `AttachPrismaticJoint` on line 88; this line seems like it will create one with the default name of `prismatic` and X axis, while on line 88 it also has `prismatic` and Z axis

can dart have joints with the same name? is this intentional?
content.html:
you also call AttachPrismaticJoint on line 88; this line seems like it will create one with the default name of prismatic and X axis, while on line 88 it also has prismatic and Z axis

can dart have joints with the same name? is this intentional?

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 7: Features for programmatic construction of objects

content.raw:
DART will automatically add a numerical suffix whenever a duplicated name is given to an object that manages a unique set of names. DART will print a notification about this to stdout when it happens, which may produce undesirable noise.

However, in this case, this prismatic joint is going to be replaced by the one that gets created on line 88, so there won’t be any point in time where the joint name would be duplicated, and so no notification would get printed.

I’m not actually sure if this is intentional, though. Nothing is done with `child` nor the prismatic joint we’re creating here; it just gets replaced by the later one. I might have intended this to be a test that joints can be replaced, although I should have left a note of that if that’s what I intended.

So I think we can either \(1\) remove this line, or \(2\) add a note explaining that is used to test that joints can be replaced.
content.html:
DART will automatically add a numerical suffix whenever a duplicated name is given to an object that manages a unique set of names. DART will print a notification about this to stdout when it happens, which may produce undesirable noise.

However, in this case, this prismatic joint is going to be replaced by the one that gets created on line 88, so there won’t be any point in time where the joint name would be duplicated, and so no notification would get printed.

I’m not actually sure if this is intentional, though. Nothing is done with child nor the prismatic joint we’re creating here; it just gets replaced by the later one. I might have intended this to be a test that joints can be replaced, although I should have left a note of that if that’s what I intended.

So I think we can either (1) remove this line, or (2) add a note explaining that is used to test that joints can be replaced.

content.raw: I think it's simplest to (1) remove this line. If we want to keep it, I think it would need more than just documentation, I think it would need some additional expectations to confirms that joint replacement is occuring.

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 7: Features for programmatic construction of objects

content.raw: I noticed that this `FixedJoint` and also `FreeJoint` inherit their `Link` functionality from `Entity`, while the other joints inherit from `Feature::Link`. I can't remember if someone asked this before, but is this intentional / does it matter?
content.html: I noticed that this FixedJoint and also FreeJoint inherit their Link functionality from Entity, while the other joints inherit from Feature::Link. I can't remember if someone asked this before, but is this intentional / does it matter?

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 7: Features for programmatic construction of objects

content.raw:
Currently it makes no difference at all. I created the the `Feature::Link` class \(and other `Feature::X` classes\) because I thought we might need to have some member functions that universal for all classes derived from `Feature::X` \(for example, the `InitiateEngine(~)` function of `Feature::Implementation`\), but so far `Feature::Implementation` is the only class for which that has been necessary.

For the sake of consistency, I'll change `Entity` to `Link` here. In the future, we can reevaluate what kind of inheritance pattern is preferable.
content.html:
Currently it makes no difference at all. I created the the Feature::Link class (and other Feature::X classes) because I thought we might need to have some member functions that universal for all classes derived from Feature::X (for example, the InitiateEngine(~) function of Feature::Implementation), but so far Feature::Implementation is the only class for which that has been necessary.

For the sake of consistency, I'll change Entity to Link here. In the future, we can reevaluate what kind of inheritance pattern is preferable.

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 7: Features for programmatic construction of objects

content.raw:
I'm curious how this would be implemented, but it looks like it hasn't been implemented yet, so that discussion can wait.

A convenient way to implement this is with distinct parameters for each surface and a function for combining the parameters of two surfaces (like `std::min` or a harmonic mean). I suspect that this doesn't capture all observable types of surface interactions, but it's a good place to start.
content.html:
I'm curious how this would be implemented, but it looks like it hasn't been implemented yet, so that discussion can wait.

A convenient way to implement this is with distinct parameters for each surface and a function for combining the parameters of two surfaces (like std::min or a harmonic mean). I suspect that this doesn't capture all observable types of surface interactions, but it's a good place to start.

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 7: Features for programmatic construction of objects

content.raw:
Yeah, strictly speaking coefficient of friction \(and restitution\) are functions of two surfaces. I know that DART stores friction/restitution coefficients per collision geometry and then does something like a geometric mean between whatever two surfaces are in contact, but I thought I’d write an API that’s more true to real physics in case any physics engine supports that kind of parameterization.

Like you said, this is just a prototype which is currently unused and unimplemented, so we can have a more in depth discussion later whenever we’re ready for it.
content.html:
Yeah, strictly speaking coefficient of friction (and restitution) are functions of two surfaces. I know that DART stores friction/restitution coefficients per collision geometry and then does something like a geometric mean between whatever two surfaces are in contact, but I thought I’d write an API that’s more true to real physics in case any physics engine supports that kind of parameterization.

Like you said, this is just a prototype which is currently unused and unimplemented, so we can have a more in depth discussion later whenever we’re ready for it.

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 7: Features for programmatic construction of objects

content.raw: I think we need a constructor for `ignition::physics::Entity` that takes an rvalue reference of for the first argument in order for the `std::move` to have an effect.  Otherwise, the `newPimpl` will be copied when when `EntityT` is constructed.
content.html: I think we need a constructor for ignition::physics::Entity that takes an rvalue reference of for the first argument in order for the std::move to have an effect. Otherwise, the newPimpl will be copied when when EntityT is constructed.

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 7: Features for programmatic construction of objects

content.raw:
Yes.  I had to add the following in order for the move constructor of `std::shared_ptr` to be called \(sorry for the verbosity\).

‌

```diff
diff -r 20c870a6887a include/ignition/physics/Entity.hh
--- a/include/ignition/physics/Entity.hh	Fri Oct 05 21:17:34 2018 -0500
+++ b/include/ignition/physics/Entity.hh	Mon Oct 08 19:18:20 2018 -0500
@@ -243,6 +243,9 @@
         const std::shared_ptr<Pimpl> &_pimpl = nullptr,
         const Identity &_identity = Identity());
 
+      protected: Entity(
+        std::shared_ptr<Pimpl> &&_pimpl,
+        const Identity &_identity = Identity());
       /// \brief Get a pointer to the implementation of FeatureT.
       ///
       /// This is a convenience function so that entities don't have to query
diff -r 20c870a6887a include/ignition/physics/detail/Entity.hh
--- a/include/ignition/physics/detail/Entity.hh	Fri Oct 05 21:17:34 2018 -0500
+++ b/include/ignition/physics/detail/Entity.hh	Mon Oct 08 19:18:20 2018 -0500
@@ -329,6 +329,15 @@
       // Do nothing
     }
 
+    template <typename Policy, typename Features>
+    Entity<Policy, Features>::Entity(
+        std::shared_ptr<Pimpl> &&_pimpl,
+        const Identity &_identity)
+      : pimpl(std::move(_pimpl)),
+        identity(_identity)
+    {
+      // Do nothing
+    }
     /////////////////////////////////////////////////
     template <typename Policy, typename Features>
     template <typename FeatureT>
diff -r 20c870a6887a include/ignition/physics/detail/FeatureList.hh
--- a/include/ignition/physics/detail/FeatureList.hh	Fri Oct 05 21:17:34 2018 -0500
+++ b/include/ignition/physics/detail/FeatureList.hh	Mon Oct 08 19:18:20 2018 -0500
@@ -457,6 +457,9 @@
     public: X(const std::shared_ptr<typename Base::Pimpl> &_pimpl, \
               const Identity &_identity) \
       : Entity<PolicyT, FeaturesT>(_pimpl, _identity) { } \
+    public: X(std::shared_ptr<typename Base::Pimpl> &&_pimpl, \
+              const Identity &_identity) \
+      : Entity<PolicyT, FeaturesT>(std::move(_pimpl), _identity) { } \
   }; \
   template <typename PolicyT, typename FeaturesT> \
   using X ## Ptr = ::ignition::physics::EntityPtr< \
```
content.html:
Yes. I had to add the following in order for the move constructor of std::shared_ptr to be called (sorry for the verbosity).

‌

diff -r 20c870a6887a include/ignition/physics/Entity.hh
--- a/include/ignition/physics/Entity.hh    Fri Oct 05 21:17:34 2018 -0500
+++ b/include/ignition/physics/Entity.hh    Mon Oct 08 19:18:20 2018 -0500
@@ -243,6 +243,9 @@
         const std::shared_ptr<Pimpl> &_pimpl = nullptr,
         const Identity &_identity = Identity());

+      protected: Entity(
+        std::shared_ptr<Pimpl> &&_pimpl,
+        const Identity &_identity = Identity());
       /// \brief Get a pointer to the implementation of FeatureT.
       ///
       /// This is a convenience function so that entities don't have to query
diff -r 20c870a6887a include/ignition/physics/detail/Entity.hh
--- a/include/ignition/physics/detail/Entity.hh Fri Oct 05 21:17:34 2018 -0500
+++ b/include/ignition/physics/detail/Entity.hh Mon Oct 08 19:18:20 2018 -0500
@@ -329,6 +329,15 @@
       // Do nothing
     }

+    template <typename Policy, typename Features>
+    Entity<Policy, Features>::Entity(
+        std::shared_ptr<Pimpl> &&_pimpl,
+        const Identity &_identity)
+      : pimpl(std::move(_pimpl)),
+        identity(_identity)
+    {
+      // Do nothing
+    }
     /////////////////////////////////////////////////
     template <typename Policy, typename Features>
     template <typename FeatureT>
diff -r 20c870a6887a include/ignition/physics/detail/FeatureList.hh
--- a/include/ignition/physics/detail/FeatureList.hh    Fri Oct 05 21:17:34 2018 -0500
+++ b/include/ignition/physics/detail/FeatureList.hh    Mon Oct 08 19:18:20 2018 -0500
@@ -457,6 +457,9 @@
     public: X(const std::shared_ptr<typename Base::Pimpl> &_pimpl, \
               const Identity &_identity) \
       : Entity<PolicyT, FeaturesT>(_pimpl, _identity) { } \
+    public: X(std::shared_ptr<typename Base::Pimpl> &&_pimpl, \
+              const Identity &_identity) \
+      : Entity<PolicyT, FeaturesT>(std::move(_pimpl), _identity) { } \
   }; \
   template <typename PolicyT, typename FeaturesT> \
   using X ## Ptr = ::ignition::physics::EntityPtr< \
